key_channel_insights.line_content: Predominantly higher fares than direct, with minimal undercutting and notable coverage gaps on long-haul.
Strong price advantage over direct in most cases, very few instances of higher fares, and stable coverage.
Mostly higher fares compared to direct, fewer lower-price cases, and stable but improving coverage percentage.

conclusion.line_content: This report provides a high-level summary of the price discrepancies observed across different channels.  It is important to note that the data contains many nuances depending on various factors such as market conditions, booking windows, and the competitive landscape. Understanding these subtleties can be critical in optimizing pricing strategies and ensuring competitive positioning.

As part of our 'PriceEye' solution, we are developing an intuitive dashboard designed to help your airline's analysts drill down into this data. This tool will allow you to uncover and focus on critical actionable insights, enabling your team to make data-driven decisions with confidence.

We are here to support you in leveraging these insights to enhance your revenue management and distribution strategies. Please don't hesitate to connect with our team for more information about how PriceEye can assist you in achieving your business objectives.

ota_highlights.line_content: Over 70% of last-week checks have OTA above the airline website, a slight rise from the prior week but below last month’s peak.
Under 1% of itineraries appear cheaper on OTA, with minor week-on-week changes.
Nearly 30% of long-haul itineraries have no matching OTA fare, roughly triple the short-haul gap.

ota_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: Around 12% lack a comparable OTA listing, holding steady versus last week but marginally down from last month.
Approximately 13% match the website’s fares, with minimal fluctuations across the observed periods.
Dominant status at 73% last week, up 2% from the prior week but down 2% from last month.
Remains rare at about 1% of cases, reflecting limited undercutting by the channel.

ota_summary_by_region.line_content: OTA pricing is higher 76% of the time, rising 2% from last week, overshadowing the 14% with matching fares.
Although OTA is higher in 57% of cases, coverage gaps reach 29%, nearly triple the short-haul figure.

ota_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: OTA is higher for 74% of itineraries, with only an 8% coverage gap and a relatively larger 17% price match.
OTA higher sits at 73%, but the gap grows to 24%, and matching fares remain negligible at around 2%.

ota_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: OTA higher rates drop to 72% (down 4% from last week), while about 1% see lower OTA fares.
OTA higher surges to 75%, a 13% climb over the prior week, with close to 0% cheaper fares available.

mse_highlights.line_content: Over 77% of itineraries were priced lower on MSE versus the website, peaking above 92% for Norway origins.
MSE higher instances remain below 0.1% for most segments, indicating almost no price disadvantage to the website.
The 'SAME' category remains modest overall but shows expansion in certain long-haul and Non-NO segments.

mse_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: A small but steady share (around 9% overall) where the website fare was not matched on MSE.
Still below 10% in most groups but climbing for longer hauls and Non-NO, suggesting emerging price parity.
Negligible incidence—often below 0.1%—with no significant spikes across regions or seasons.
Consistently the largest category, exceeding 80% in many segments, signaling a strong undercut of website fares.

mse_summary_by_region.line_content: MSE Lower leads at 85.77% last week; minor changes week to week indicate stable undercutting of direct fares.
83.24% of fares came in lower on MSE last week, showing a 7.26% increase over the previous period.

mse_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: 92.11% of itineraries were cheaper on MSE last week, with minimal Same or Higher scenarios.
Two-thirds were MSE Lower, while Same reached 16% and is rising, hinting at selective fare alignment.

mse_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: MSE lowers around 85.82% of close-in fares, with Same dropping to just under 5% last week.
A robust 84.94% of advance bookings were priced lower on MSE, only 6.22% matched website fares.

gds_highlights.line_content: Over 70% of itineraries remain priced higher on GDS than on the website, with minimal week-over-week fluctuation.
Below 1% of cases are cheaper on GDS, reinforcing the channel’s predominantly higher pricing trend.
Approximately 15% of website fares were not found on GDS, slightly lower than the previous week.

gds_summary_high_level_comparison.line_content: Around 15% of fares were absent on GDS last week, a slight dip indicating steadily improving coverage.
Parity held for about 13% of itineraries, with negligible changes from last week and modest growth over last month.
Roughly 71% of fares showed a premium on GDS, reflecting a dominant trend with only minor historical fluctuations.
Fewer than 1% of fares appeared cheaper on GDS, showing little change from prior periods.

gds_summary_by_region.line_content: 74% of short-haul fares cost more in GDS, with under 1% cheaper, indicating limited downward pricing.
About half of long-haul fares are GDS-higher; 3.5% are lower, a relatively larger share than short haul.

gds_summary_by_point_of_origin.line_content: 74% of fares run higher on GDS, with under 9% not found, reflecting strong coverage and premium pricing.
65% of fares are GDS-higher, while around 31% are missing, suggesting greater coverage gaps than Norway.

gds_summary_by_booking_window.line_content: 70% of near-departure fares price higher in GDS, with 1.3% cheaper but a slightly higher rate of missing fares.
74% of long-lead fares are GDS-higher, with minimal cheaper cases and lower instances of missing fares.
